title: 111_hr6279
content: The Act is titled the "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act." It allows for the temporary retention of reserves on active duty after demobilization following extended deployments in contingency operations or homeland defense missions. The "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act" allows for the temporary retention of reserves on active duty for 45 days after demobilization from deployments lasting more than 179 days in contingency operations. The "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act" allows for the temporary retention of reserves on active duty for specific missions, ensuring they receive basic pay, subsistence allowance, and housing allowance. Members can request early release from active duty. The "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act" allows for the temporary retention of reserves on active duty for specific missions. Members can request early release from active duty, which can only be denied for medical or personal safety reasons by an officer above O-5. If the request is not denied within 14 days, it is deemed approved, and the member will be released as requested. The "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act" allows for the temporary retention of reserves on active duty for specific missions. Members can request early release from active duty, which can only be denied for medical or personal safety reasons by an officer above O-5. The Secretary of the military department concerned shall provide counseling and services to assist retained members in reintegrating into civilian life, including physical and mental health evaluations, employment counseling, marriage and family counseling, financial management counseling, education counseling, and assistance on benefits available through the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "National Guard and Reserve Soft Landing Reintegration Act" mandates counseling and services for retained members to aid in their transition to civilian life. Family members may participate, services should be provided at convenient locations, and coordination with the Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Program is required. Chapter 1209 of the title is amended to include a new item. Reserves: temporary retention on active duty after demobilization following extended deployments in contingency operations or homeland defense missions.
